title: Ashes Hollow Walk Route

images.title: Geoff Pick / Ashes Hollow
images.caption: Walkers on a rocky crag above the Quinny Brook. The source is a spring called Boiling Well on the dissected plateau of the Long Mynd, adjacent to a number of Long barrows.

images.title: Bob Bowyer / Ashes Hollow
images.caption: Looking upstream - tributary entering from the right - possible cone to the left - valley is perceptably narrowing. After passing through Little Stretton, the brrok heads south towards Marshbrook and Strefford. To the north of Strefford, it is joined by its main tributary the Byne Brook.

images.title: Stream at Ashes Hollow, Long Mynd by Dave Croker, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Stream at Ashes Hollow, Long Mynd

images.title: Hazy morning sunlight in Ashes Hollow by Jeremy Bolwell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Hazy morning sunlight in Ashes Hollow

images.title: Ashes Hollow by David Martin, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Ashes Hollow

images.title: Arisen from the Ashes? No longer derelict, anyway. by Richard Law, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Arisen from the Ashes. No longer derelict, anyway. A remote house next to the path.

images.title: Dennis simpson / Footbridge
images.caption: Small footbridge built to carry walkers, climbing or descending Long Mynd.

images.title: Jerry Evans / Looking upstream towards Ashes Hollow
images.caption: Looking upstream towards Ashes Hollow

description: This walk explores Ashes Hollow near the villages of Church Stretton and Little Stretton in the Shropshire Hills. The V shaped valley is home to the Quinny Brook, a tributary stream of the River Onny. It's a lovely place for a walk with waterside footpaths along the pretty brook which is flanked by some beautiful hills and attractive vegetation. You can start the walk in Little Stretton and head north to pick up the trail along the brook. The stream continues up to the Long Mynd where you can enjoy some wonderful views from the elevated ridge.
